heading: 1 Workshop 1: Data Handling Skills
text: Aims:Practice importing .csv data file RStudio using read_csv()Practice importing .csv data file RStudio using read_csv()Practice inspecting data RStudio.Practice inspecting data RStudio.Use different data wrangling functions develop data handling skills.Use different data wrangling functions develop data handling skills.Check basic summary statistics.Check basic summary statistics.

heading: 1.1 Exercise 1: Import the Data
text: Import Data File guess_who.csvBefore begin, need tidyverse package loaded.Next import data file store object called dataset.see error saying find function read_csv() usually means loaded (installed) tidyverse package.
code:
install.packages("tidyverse") #install tidyverse if you do not have it.
library(tidyverse) #loads tidyverse.
dataset <- read_csv("guess_who.csv")

heading: 1.2 Exercise 2: Inspect and Check Your Data
text: Take look newly imported data fileCheck top right panel (environment) also use code inspect data set.really important look variable names ’ll using code later .Answer Question 2.1 - 2.2 worksheet.
code:
view(dataset) # this will open the data in a new tab.
names(dataset) # this will show the variable names.

heading: 1.3 Exercise 3: Change a Variable Name
text: One variable names quite long. can annoying keep typing outChange variable name do_you_own_a_pet pet. rename() function let rename variable.Check worked:
code:
dataset <- dataset %>%
  rename(pet = do_you_own_a_pet)
names(dataset) # ask for the variable names again

heading: 1.4 Exercise 4: Remove a Variable
text: really care age variable next exercises.Let’s remove .code create new object (start removing things, best keep original data file called dataset environment)code :Create new object called mydata.Create new object called mydata.Take original data called datasetTake original data called dataset“” %>%“” %>%Use select() function remove age placing minus symbol - front .Use select() function remove age placing minus symbol - front .now , use object called mydata original data set.
code:
mydata <- dataset %>%
  select(-age)

heading: 1.5 Exercise 5: Filter Cases
text: can select particular cases data setFor example, ask: many people city Birmingham using code :Check console (bottom left panel) answer.code :Take mydata …Take mydata …Filter city variable.Filter city variable.use double equals symbol == specify exact match.use double equals symbol == specify exact match.’ve added “birmingham” speech marks. Note lowercase match data set …’ve added “birmingham” speech marks. Note lowercase match data set …count() number data points.count() number data points.Adapt code answer question 5.1 worksheet.
code:
mydata %>%
  filter(city == "birmingham") %>%
  count()

heading: 1.6 Exercise 6: Guess Who?
text: can filter based multiple criteria.code show us someone Brighton, dog, drink coffee.can also use less /symbols filter data, example, show people maths enjoyment score less 20:Use learned adapt code play GUESS ? complete questions 6.1-6.2 worksheet.
code:
mydata %>%
  filter(city == "brighton", pet == "dog", coffee == 0)
mydata %>%
  filter(maths < 20)

heading: 1.7 Exercise 7: Create a New Variable
text: Sometimes might want compute new scores variablesAdd three enjoyment scores maths, science, art create overall score called total_score.code :Take mydata overwrite (ready add new variable) …Take mydata overwrite (ready add new variable) …Use mutate() function create new variable named total_score equal = maths + science + art.Use mutate() function create new variable named total_score equal = maths + science + art.View data set look new column see worked.Now, can look highest lowest total enjoyment score.slice_min find row lowest score:slice_max find row highest score:Answer questions 7.1-7.2 worksheet.
code:
mydata <- mydata %>%
  mutate(total_score = maths + science + art)
view(mydata)
mydata %>%
  slice_min(total_score)
mydata %>%
  slice_max(total_score)

heading: 1.8 Exercise 8: Counting and Removing Missing Data
text: Real data sets often missing data pointsDifferent people differing views treat missing data points. today, just identify remove . view data, might notice blanks degree everyone studying one.code :Calculate total number using sum() …Calculate total number using sum() …missing data points (R calls .na)missing data points (R calls .na)can direct particular column using mydata$degree. essentially means “look mydata column called degree. use dollar sign $ specify column.can direct particular column using mydata$degree. essentially means “look mydata column called degree. use dollar sign $ specify column.want remove , can use filter() !Note: overwrite mydata remove cases.Answer question 8.1 worksheet.
code:
sum(is.na(mydata$degree))
mydata <- mydata %>% 
  filter(!is.na(degree))

heading: 1.9 Exercise 9: Summary Statistics
text: might want know average enjoyment score?can use code look across data set whole:Look output console (bottom left panel) answer questions 9.1-9.3 worksheet.
code: summary(mydata)

text: Help!! code working. need help fix …Fix code work many coffees drunk person canterbury studying medicine. Try running code first work doesn’t work!Fix code work name person London, hamster, studies psychology, drink coffee. Try running code first work doesn’t work!Answer questions 10.1-10.2 worksheet.get stuck, use hints .Check spelling errors: two .Check spelling errors: two .Make sure use double equals specifying label ==.Make sure use double equals specifying label ==.Use quote marks necessary. missing.Use quote marks necessary. missing.Code case sensitive. capital letter shouldn’t one.Code case sensitive. capital letter shouldn’t one.Use symbols correctly. want use pipe %>% filter.Use symbols correctly. want use pipe %>% filter.Use symbols correctly. > <.Use symbols correctly. > <.Well Done. reached end workshop.
code:
mydata %>%
  filter(city = "canterburY", degree == medicine)
mydata =
  filter(city == "London", pet == "hamsta", degree == "psychology", coffee >1)

heading: 2 Workshop 2: Summarising and Describing Data
text: Aims:Practice importing .csv data file RStudio using read_csv()Practice importing .csv data file RStudio using read_csv()Practice inspecting data RStudio.Practice inspecting data RStudio.Calculate mean standard deviation using group_by() summarise() functions.Calculate mean standard deviation using group_by() summarise() functions.Visually inspect data using plots describe data distributions.Visually inspect data using plots describe data distributions.

heading: 2.1 Exercise 1: Import the Data
text: Import Data File: stroop.csvBefore begin, need tidyverse package loaded.Next import data file store object called dataset.see error saying find function read_csv() usually means loaded (installed) tidyverse package.
code:
install.packages("tidyverse") #install tidyverse if you do not have it.
library(tidyverse) #loads tidyverse.
dataset <- read_csv("stroop.csv")

heading: 2.2 Exercise 2: Inspect and Check Your Data
text: Take look newly imported data fileCheck top right panel (environment) also use code inspect data set.really important look variable names ’ll using code later .
code:
view(dataset) # this will open the data in a new tab.
names(dataset) # this will show the variable names.

heading: 2.3 Exercise 3: Calculate the Stroop Inteference Score
text: Sometimes might want compute new scores variablesCalculate Stroop interference measure. difference incongruent congruent conditions. Take incongruent reaction times subtract congruent reaction times using code :code :Create object called mydata using original dataset …Create object called mydata using original dataset …Use mutate() function create new variable named int equal = incongruent - (minus) congruent.Use mutate() function create new variable named int equal = incongruent - (minus) congruent.View data set look new column see worked. Note: check final column see int appeared.exactly Stroop Interference thingy? want learn , see .interference measure milliseconds (msecs) amount extra time took participant answer incongruent (trickier trials colours match word) compared congruent trials (easier trial colours match work).sense, many milliseconds slower need focus attention engage executive functions fight urge read word rather name colour.smaller number perhaps indicative better attention/executive functioning processes!Answer questions 3.1-3.2 worksheet.
code:
mydata <- dataset %>%
  mutate(int = incongruent - congruent)
view(mydata)

heading: 2.4 Exercise 4: Calculate Descriptive Statistics
text: Just shown lecture, use code calculate mean standard deviation Stroop interference int. Remember, want use int calculated exercise 3.need change NULL match data set. Try give go first, aren’t sure look help.Think :NULL1: name variable split data file (e.g., grouping variable/independent variable called mydata)NULL1: name variable split data file (e.g., grouping variable/independent variable called mydata)NULL2: name score want find mean standard deviation (e.g., dependent variable called mydata)NULL2: name score want find mean standard deviation (e.g., dependent variable called mydata)look environment (top right panel) see new object called desc. descriptive statistics stored. called desc can call anything like. best keep object names short informative. can now view object using view() function.Answer questions 4.1-4.2 worksheet.
code:
desc <-  mydata %>%
  group_by(NULL1) %>%
  summarise(mean_int = mean(NULL2),
            sd_int = sd(NULL2))
desc <-  mydata %>%
  group_by(drink) %>%
  summarise(mean_int = mean(int),
            sd_int = sd(int))
view(desc)

heading: 2.5 Exercise 5: Explore Data with Plots
text: Generate box plot:Generate histograms:Generate density plots:Answer questions 5.1-5.2 worksheet.
code:
ggplot(mydata, aes(x = drink, y = int)) +
  geom_boxplot(width = .4)
ggplot(mydata, aes(x = int, fill = drink)) +
  geom_histogram(colour = "black") +
  facet_wrap(~ drink)
ggplot(mydata, aes(x = int, fill = drink)) +
  geom_density(alpha = .5) +
  facet_wrap(~ drink)

heading: 2.6 Exercise 6: What Does facet_wrap() do?
text: Re-run density plot code, except time delete final line. show facet_wrap() . notice plot now?Use code without facet_wrap().Answer question 6.1 worksheet.
code:
ggplot(mydata, aes(x = int, fill = drink)) +
  geom_density(alpha = .5)

Make sure know saved computer leave. need file next week!Well Done. reached end workshop.
code: write.csv(mydata, "stroop.csv")

heading: 3 Workshop 3: t-tests
text: Aims:Practice running interpreting two-sample t-test RStudio.Practice running interpreting two-sample t-test RStudio.Practice running interpreting paired t-test RStudio.Practice running interpreting paired t-test RStudio.Part OnePart one today’s workshop involved running two-sample t-test, appropriate independent measures design two groups.use data file last week, aiming investigate whether Stroop interference scores (msecs) significantly differ Red Cow group control group.must completed week 2 workshop starting one.

heading: 3.1 Exercise 1: Import the Data
text: Import Data File: stroop.csvBefore begin, need following packages:import data file. Make sure int score calculated last week. , need go back complete workshop 2.
code:
install.packages("tidyverse") #install if needed.
install.packages("rstatix")   #install if needed.
install.packages("car")       #install if needed.
library(tidyverse)            #load package.
library(rstatix)              #load package.
library(car)                  #load package.
mydata <- read_csv("stroop.csv")

heading: 3.2 Exercise 2: Inspect and Check Your Data
text: Take look newly imported data fileCheck top right panel (environment) also use code inspect data set.really important look variable names ’ll using code later .
code:
view(mydata) # this will open the data in a new tab.
names(mydata) # this will show the variable names.

heading: 3.3.1 Check Heteroscedasticity with Levene’s Test
text: need just use Welch’s t-test instead.need justify decision (e.g., 3rd Year Project), following papers might help:Delacre et al. (2017)Delacre et al. (2017)Ruxton (2006)Ruxton (2006)gentler explanation, see also blog post Daniel Lakens.gentler explanation, see also blog post Daniel Lakens.

heading: 3.3.2 Check Normality with Shapiro-Wilk Test and Histograms
text: need check normality groups separately. can filter groups:use dollar sign $ point R particular column. example, using shapiro.test(redcow$int) saying run Shapiro Test redcow data set specific column called intAgain, want p-values significant. non-significant p-value means data roughly normally distributed. p-value significant, issue indicates data normally distributed.reporting Shapiro-Wilk test, just need report test statistics (w = XX) p-value. example look like:W = 0.98, p = .875You can also visually check data quick histogram:Check plots panel, use blue arrow switch two plots.
code:
#first create a data set that contains the control group only
control <- mydata %>%
  filter(drink == "control")
#then run the test
shapiro.test(control$int)

#then create a data set that contains Red Cow drinkers only
redcow <- mydata %>%
  filter(drink == "redcow")
#then run the test
shapiro.test(redcow$int)
hist(control$int)
hist(redcow$int)

heading: 3.4 Exercise 4: Run the Two-Sample t-Test and ask for Cohen’s d
text: Run t-test.Ask Cohen’s d:Interpret t-test.test significant?test significant?effect size?effect size?significant, groups differ (e.g., use descriptive statistics interpret difference)?significant, groups differ (e.g., use descriptive statistics interpret difference)?Hint: re-use code last week find mean standard deviation two groups.Hint: re-use code last week find mean standard deviation two groups.Answer questions 4.1-4.3 worksheet.
code:
t.test(int ~ drink, data = mydata, var.equal = FALSE, alternative = "two.sided")
cohens_d(data = mydata, int ~ drink, var.equal = FALSE)

heading: 3.5 Part 2 - Exercise 5: Import the Data
text: Part Two StudyPart two today’s workshop involved running paired t-test, appropriate repeated measures design two conditions.Let’s switch bit use different scenario experiment new data set.look someone’s resting heart rate might change result drinking can Red Cow.study resting heart rate beats per minute (BPM) measured group participants consuming can Red Cow.independent variable time point: , . dependent variable BPM.Import DataWe call object dat (short name data)
code: dat <- read_csv("bpm.csv")

heading: 3.6 Exercise 6: Inspect and Check Your Data
text: Take look newly imported data fileCheck top right panel (environment) also use code inspect data set.
code:
view(dat) # this will open the data in a new tab.
names(dat) # this will show the variable names.

heading: 3.7 Exercise 7: Check Assumptions
text: need check normality, heteroscedasiticty apply repeated measures designs. However, need ensure difference score normally distributed.interpret report way earlier (exercise 3).Answer questions 7.1-7.2 worksheet.
code:
diff <- dat$after - dat$before  #this will calculate the difference score.
shapiro.test(diff)              # run the Shapiro test
hist(diff)                      # also visually inspect data

heading: 3.8 Exercise 8: Run the Paired t-Test and ask for Cohen’s d
text: paired t-test little different compared two-sample t-test.Change NULL1 column first condition.Change NULL1 column first condition.Change NULL2 column second condition.Change NULL2 column second condition.(Hint: need use dollar sign $ specify data set column, e.g., dat$NULL1 dat$NULL2).Try first, need, check solution .Annoyingly, need use different package Cohen’s d paired t-test.Answer questions 8.1-8.2 worksheet. Hint: also need descriptive statistics (see exercise 9 ).
code:
t.test(NULL1, NULL2, paired = TRUE)
t.test(dat$before, dat$after, paired = TRUE)
install.packages("effectsize") #install if needed.
library(effectsize)
effectsize::cohens_d(dat$before, dat$after, paired = TRUE)

heading: 3.9 Exercise 9: Calculate Descriptive Statistics
text: final thing convert data wide format long format. Often repeated measures asking descriptive statistics plots, need data long format.Code explanation:Create new object called longd store long data.Create new object called longd store long data.Base original data set called dat %>%Base original data set called dat %>%pivot_longer()pivot_longer()first argument include columns contain dependent variable. case use :afterwhich take columns (columns just take two ).first argument include columns contain dependent variable. case use :afterwhich take columns (columns just take two ).Next use names_to = tell R want call independent variable. used “time” time point study.Next use names_to = tell R want call independent variable. used “time” time point study.use values_to = tell R want call dependent variable. measure beats per minute, just called “bpm”.use values_to = tell R want call dependent variable. measure beats per minute, just called “bpm”.Pay careful attention lay code. example, notice brackets open close, placement commas move next line.Pay careful attention lay code. example, notice brackets open close, placement commas move next line.created new long data set called longd can use calculate descriptive statistics. first check see difference.Now adapt code ask mean standard deviation.Change NULL1 name independent variable long data file, NULL2 dependent variable. tricky, use names(longd) need reminder variable names revisit notes last week’s workshop.Make note mean standard deviation conditions.Try first, need, check solution .Well Done. reached end workshop.
code:
longd <- dat %>%
  pivot_longer(
              before:after,
              names_to = "time",
              values_to = "bpm"
              )
view(longd)
names(longd)desc <- longd %>%
  group_by(NULL1) %>%
  summarise(mean_bpm = mean(NULL2)
            sd_bpm = sd(NULL2))
desc <- longd %>%
  group_by(time) %>%
  summarise(mean_bpm = mean(bpm),
            sd_bpm = sd(bpm))

view(desc)

heading: 4 Workshop 4: One-Way ANOVA (Model, Designs, Assumptions)
text: Aims:Practice running one-way ANOVAs repeated independent measures designs.Practice checking ANOVA assumptions interpreting ANOVA model output.Part OnePart one today’s workshop involve running one-way ANOVA repeated measures design.Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) occurs wen someone begins difficulty memory cognitive abilities, however, (1) usually significant enough interfere general activities daily living (2) fully meet criteria dementia.data set contains data new memory assessment used individuals MCI across four year period (participant assessed per year).Using one-way ANOVA, can determine happens memory scores time?

heading: 4.1 Exercise 1: Import the Data
text: Import Data FileBefore begin need packages loaded.Next import data file store object called dat.
code:
library(tidyverse) # should already be installed.

install.packages("afex") # install if needed
install.packages("car") #install if needed
library(afex)
library(car)
dat <- read_csv("mci.csv")

heading: 4.2 Exercise 2: Inspect and Check Your Data
text: Take look newly imported data fileCheck top right panel (environment) also use code inspect dataset.data wide format long format?data wide, need convert long format using code .explanation code line line. one little tricky.First, create new object called mydata base existing dat …First, create new object called mydata base existing dat …Pivot data (long wide) taking columns starting year1 year4. stating year1:year4 telling take columns year1 year4, including anything . Essentially stating first final levels independent variable.Pivot data (long wide) taking columns starting year1 year4. stating year1:year4 telling take columns year1 year4, including anything . Essentially stating first final levels independent variable.names_to include name assign independent variable. study time point just use time shorter.names_to include name assign independent variable. study time point just use time shorter.values_to include name assign dependent variable. study memory assessment score, just use memory.values_to include name assign dependent variable. study memory assessment score, just use memory.Run code check mydata see worked.now use mydata object, long format.
code:
view(dat) # open data in new tab
names(dat) # print variable names to console
mydata <- dat %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = year1:year4,
               names_to = "time",
               values_to = "memory")
view(mydata)
names(mydata)

heading: 4.3 Exercise 3: Check Descriptives
text: Using code , generate descriptive statistics look mean memory score across time.Also, visualise data using box plot density plot.facet_wrap() missing density plots, however, feel beneficial aid interpretation, can add .
code:
desc <- mydata %>%
  group_by(time) %>%
  summarise(m_memory = mean(memory),
            sd_memory = sd(memory))
            
view(desc) # view the descriptive stats
ggplot(mydata, aes(x = time, y = memory)) +
  geom_boxplot(width = .4)ggplot(mydata, aes(x = memory, fill = time)) +
  geom_density(alpha = .5)

heading: 4.4 Exercise 4: Check Assumptions
text: Run ANOVA modelBefore start looking assumptions, need run store initial ANOVA model.Checking NormalityFirst, look see assumption normality met. look three things.QQ-PlotThe histogramThe Shapiro-Wilk testChecking SphericityTo check sphericity, need produce model output.Look output find: “Mauchly Tests Sphericity”.provide test statistic, reported using W = XX.XXIt provide p-value statistic. test, non-significant p-value means assumption met. non-significant p-value one larger value .05. significant p-value one smaller .05.looks though p-value smaller .05 assumption violated. uh-oh!
code:
mod <- aov_ez(id = "id",
              dv = "memory",
              within = "time",
              type = 3,
              include_aov = TRUE,
              data = mydata)
#testing normality, looking at normal distribution of residuals from the model.
residuals <- residuals(mod) #pulls residuals from the model

# produce QQ-Plot
qqPlot(residuals) #produces a qq-plot of residuals

# produce histogram of residuals
hist(residuals, breaks = 20, main = "Histogram of Residuals", xlab = "Residuals", col = "lightblue") 

# Shapiro test on residuals
shapiro.test(residuals) #Shapiro test for residuals
summary(mod) # provides the output of the main ANOVA model with Sphericity output.

heading: 4.5 Exercise 5: Interpret the ANOVA Model
text: easier streamlined output interpret model, use code :interpret way explained lecture. Particularly noting F, degrees freedom (two values), p-value (noting whether significant ).model simply tells us: reject null hypothesis.significant result, F(2.15, 105.54) = 127.16, p<.001, can reject null hypothesis least one conditions differs. differ yet know learn next week…
code: mod$anova_table

heading: 4.8 Exercise 8: Check Assumptions
text: start looking assumptions, need run store initial ANOVA model. four NULL values need change code match new data set.save model object called mod1.Checking NormalityFirst, look see assumption normality met. look three things.QQ-PlotThe histogramThe Shapiro-Wilk testChecking Homogeneity VarianceRun interpret Levene’s test using code :
code:
mod1 <- aov_ez(id = "NULL",
              dv = "NULL",
              between = "NULL",
              type = 3,
              include_aov = TRUE,
              data = NULL)
#testing normality, looking at normal distribution of residuals from the model.
residuals <- residuals(mod1) #pulls residuals from the model, note name is `mod1`

# produce QQ-Plot
qqPlot(residuals) #produces a qq-plot of residuals

# produce histogram of residuals
hist(residuals, breaks = 20, main = "Histogram of Residuals", xlab = "Residuals", col = "lightblue") 

# Shapiro test on residuals
shapiro.test(residuals) #Shapiro test for residuals
leveneTest(score ~ group, mydata1)

heading: 5 Workshop 5: One-Way ANOVA (Post-hocs, Contrasts, Write-up)
text: Aims:Practice using post-hoc test interpret ANOVAPractice using planned contrast interpret ANOVA result.Practice writing-results ANOVA, using APA style.Part One

heading: 5.1 Exercise 1: Import Data and Run Model
text: Last week ran one-way repeated measures ANOVA looking memory assessment score time. week need dataset code () run initial model.Remember - already checked assumptions ANOVA model significant, case now practice using planned contrast.save time, use code load necessary packages, import data, run model. Try running code save time (highlight run ). Make sure working directory set correctly first find mci.csv file.
code:
install.packages("afex") # install if needed
install.packages("car") #install if needed
library(tidyverse)
library(afex)
library(car)

dat <- read_csv("mci.csv")
mydata <- dat %>%

pivot_longer(cols = year1:year4,
               names_to = "time",
               values_to = "memory")
               
mod <- aov_ez(id = "id",
              dv = "memory",
              within = "time",
              type = 3,
              include_aov = TRUE,
              data = mydata)
              
mod$anova_table

heading: 5.2 Exercise 2: Estimated Marginal Means (EMMs)
text: code import data, switch long format, run model.model significant, need pull estimated marginal means.need specific package :Next, pull EMMs save object called emms.Now let’s say alternate hypothesis study linear decline memory scores time, use polynomial contrast. look trend. Polynomial contrasts suitable independent variable considered “continuous” nature, e.g., time point.Use code run contrast.Look output. Remember, look p-values less .05 (p < .05).significant linear, quadratic, cubic trend?Additionally, use code visualise .
code:
install.packages("emmeans") # install if needed.
library(emmeans)
emms <- emmeans(mod, ~ time)
poly <- contrast(emms, method = "poly")

print(poly) # print the results to the console
#let's visualise the data to help our interpretation
ggplot(mydata, aes(x = time, y = memory, fill = time)) +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "line", color = "black", size = 1, aes(group = 1)) + 
  theme_classic() +
  labs(title = "Plot of Memory Score Across Time",  # add a title
       x = "Time Point",  # X-axis label
       y = "Memory Score")  # Y-axis label

heading: 5.3 Part 2 - Exercise 3: Import the Data
text: Part TwoPart two workshop use dataset ANOVA model part two workshop 4 (last week).Ensure correct data file loaded.file called alert.csv. Import data file save object called mydata1 (overwrite anything Part 1 case want look back).

heading: 5.4 Exercise 4: Run the ANOVA Model
text: Next, run ANOVA model save object.save model object called mod1.Last week seen model significant (p-value less .05). means reject null hypothesis least one groups signficiantly different.
code:
mod1 <- aov_ez(id = "id",
              dv = "score",
              between = "group",
              type = 3,
              include_aov = TRUE,
              data = mydata1)
              
mod1$anova_table

heading: 5.5 Exercise 5: Post-hoc Pairwise Comparisons
text: run post-hoc tests, first need pull estimated marginal means using emmeans() apply necessary p-value adjustment.exercise, use Holm adjustment.Look output interpret . conditions differ one another? Remember look p-values less .05.Also look effect sizes, can report alongside rest analysis.Use box plot also help interpretation:
code:
emmeans(mod1,
        pairwise ~ group,
        adjust = "holm")
library(rstatix)
cohens_d(mydata1, score ~ group)
#how about a box plot too

ggplot(mydata1, aes(x = group, y = score, fill = group)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_classic()

heading: 5.6 Exercise 6: Introducting the Violin Plot
text: Previously, looked density plots box plots. Ever wondered handy way look distributions box plot time? , probably . Well show anyway.Use code generate violin plot:Mow answer questions Workshop Question Sheet
code:
ggplot(mydata1, aes(x = group, y = score, fill = group)) +
  geom_violin(trim = FALSE) +  # violin plot without trimming tails

chapter: 6 Workshop 6: Factorial ANOVA: Factorial Designs and an Interactions
heading: 6.5 Exercise 5: Simple Effects Analysis (Pairwise)
text: code firstly pull estimated marginal means (EMMs) running simple pairwise comparisons Holm correction, saving object called contrastsNext, print interpret contrasts.
code:
library(emmeans)
emms <- emmeans(mod, ~ use*notify)

contrasts <- contrast(emms,
          interaction = "pairwise", 
          simple = "each", 
          combine = FALSE, 
          adjust = "holm")
print(contrasts)

chapter: 6 Workshop 6: Factorial ANOVA: Factorial Designs and an Interactions
heading: 6.6 Exercise 6: Cohen’s d for Simple Effects
text: three pairwise comparisons need three effect sizes.Using output exercises 3-6 , answer questions 3.1-3.5 worksheet.
code:
library(effectsize)

# compare notifications for the rare group
cohens_d(anx ~ notify, 
         data = filter(mydata, use == "rare"), 
         paired = FALSE)
# compare notifications for the regular group
cohens_d(anx ~ notify, 
         data = filter(mydata, use == "regular"), 
         paired = FALSE)
# compare notifications for the problematic group
# use the examples above to replace `NULL`
cohens_d(NULL ~ NULL, 
         data = filter(NULL, NULL == "NULL"), 
         paired = FALSE)

chapter: 7 Workshop 7: Factorial ANOVA: Different Designs and Assumptions
heading: 7.1 Exercise 1: Import Data
text: beginning make sure load relevant packages.data set week includes data study looking wellbeing scores exercise. Participants completing psychological wellbeing measure two different types exercise: running swimming. Participants completed conditions.Import exercise.csv inspect data set, making note variable names.Given repeated measures design, double check data long format…run , view() data file see changed. also check variable names using names()also need ensure factors coded … R also puts labels alphabetical order, makes sense place “” ahead “”, can use levels = c() make switch.
code:
library(tidyverse)
library(afex)
library(car)
mydata <- read_csv(NULL)
view(mydata)
names(mydata)
longd <- mydata %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = starts_with("before") | starts_with("after"), # columns to pivot, anything that starts with "before" or "after"
    names_to = c("time", "exercise"), # names of new columns
    names_pattern = "(before|after)_(run|swim)", # pattern to separate columns
    values_to = "wellbeing") # Name of the value column
view(longd)
names(longd)
longd$time <- factor(longd$time, levels = c("before", "after"))
longd$exercise <- factor(longd$exercise)

view(desc)

chapter: 7 Workshop 7: Factorial ANOVA: Different Designs and Assumptions
heading: 7.3 Exercise 3: Run the ANOVA Model
text: Using aov_ez() run ANOVA model. replace NULL necessary match data set workshop.successfully run model, object called mod now appear environment panel. Let’s interpret modelIs interaction significant? Decide . , use code exercises 4-6 last week’s workshop (workshop 6)., two independent variables two levels, can interpret main effects looking descriptive statistics /plots.Remember amend group_by() line code descriptives work statistics independent variable separately (shown lecture).Use hint needed.Now try amend code find descriptives main effect time.Answer questions 3.1-3.5 worksheet.
code:
mod <- aov_ez(id = "NULL",
              dv = "NULL",
              within = c("NULL", "NULL"),
              type = 3,
              include_aov = TRUE,
              data = NULL)
mod$anova_table
exercise <- longd %>%
  group_by(exercise) %>%
  summarise(m = mean(wellbeing), 
            sd = sd(wellbeing), 
            n = n())
view(exercise)

chapter: 7 Workshop 7: Factorial ANOVA: Different Designs and Assumptions
heading: 7.4 Exercise 4: Check Model Assumptions
text: assumption Sphericity automatically checked corrected (necessary). However, repeated measures design two-levels independent variable, Sphericity apply.means 2x2 repeated measures design, check normality residuals.Next week ’ll also check assumptions mixed-design, including checking homogeneity variance.next exercises important help continue develop understanding code, research methods, statistics
code:
# testing normality, looking at normal distribution of residuals from the model.
residuals <- residuals(mod) #pulls residuals from the model
qqPlot(residuals) #produces a qq-plot of residuals
hist(residuals, breaks = 20, main = "Histogram of Residuals", xlab = "Residuals", col = "lightblue") #histogram of residuals
shapiro.test(residuals) #Shapiro test for residuals

chapter: 7 Workshop 7: Factorial ANOVA: Different Designs and Assumptions
heading: 7.5 Exercise 5: Data Visualisation
text: might notice many plots initially generated R “publication” ready.code quite long, go running look graph produces.Keep mind look data visualisation little detail weeks…Consider whether figure like might useful upcoming lab report.
code:
ggplot(longd, aes(x = time, y = wellbeing, fill = exercise)) +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "bar", position = position_dodge(), color = "black") +
  stat_summary(fun.data = mean_sdl, geom = "errorbar", 
               position = position_dodge(0.9), width = 0.25) +
  labs(
    title = NULL,   # leave this as NULL because APA figures do not use titles.
    x = "Time Point",  
    y = "Mean Wellbeing Score",
    fill = "Exercise") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("run" = "slategray4", "swim" = "slategray2"), 
                    labels = c("Run", "Swim")) +
  scale_x_discrete(labels = c("before" = "Before", "after" = "After")) +
  # layer 6: add the theme to tidy up
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.border = element_rect(color = "black", fill = NA, size = 1),
    plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
    legend.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
    axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
heading: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
text:
Aims:Practice importing wrangling data ready analysis.Practice running mixed design factorial ANOVA, including interpreting model running follow-analyses.Practice evaluating model assumptions.Practice generating plots writing-analysis.IntroductionThis week’s workshop going bring together several things covered far PS2010, including right back week one workshop. Today going analyse data set starting “messy” data set right way producing fancy data visualisations show findings.steps covered today’s workshop helpful lab report analysis write-.quite steps today don’t worry complete allotted time, instead save script use independent study time complete .Today’s Research ScenarioThere lots tasks performance can negatively impacted distractions. tasks whereby solely focus , example, completing workshop driving car.distracted completing workshop, worst happen make mistake code. Distractions driving can much serious consequences. Today’s research question : distractions impact ability detect different types hazards driving.Sixty experienced drivers (minimum 1 year driving experience) recruited take part driving simulation task, whereby identify different hazards. Participants first randomly allocated one two conditions.Independent variable 1 (distraction yes/):
Yes: participants required answer questions researcher via hands free headset whilst simulator.
: participants left drive uninterrupted simulator.
Independent variable 1 (distraction yes/):Yes: participants required answer questions researcher via hands free headset whilst simulator.Yes: participants required answer questions researcher via hands free headset whilst simulator.: participants left drive uninterrupted simulator.: participants left drive uninterrupted simulator.Question 1: variable independent repeated measures? – choose answer –. Independent MeasuresB. Repeated MeasuresDuring driving simulation task, participants identify hazards (e.g., car pulling front, pedestrian stepping ) pressing button. three different types hazard participants saw.Independent variable 2 (hazard type: car, bike, pedestrian)
Car: car cause hazard.
Bike: bicycle cause hazard
Pedestrian: pedestrian cause hazard.
Independent variable 2 (hazard type: car, bike, pedestrian)Car: car cause hazard.Car: car cause hazard.Bike: bicycle cause hazardBike: bicycle cause hazardPedestrian: pedestrian cause hazard.Pedestrian: pedestrian cause hazard.Question 2: variable independent repeated measures? – choose answer –. Independent MeasuresB. Repeated MeasuresThe dependent variable study number hazards correctly identified. driving task split two blocks, maximum 10 hazards hazard type block (total 30 hazards per block).Workshop OutlineThe workshop split different parts:Exercises 1-2: Import Prepare Data Analysis involve setting RStudio, importing data, data wrangling tasks ensure data correct format prior analysis.Exercise 3: Calculate Statistics involve running initial descriptive statistics initial ANOVA model.Exercises 4-6 Carrying additional analyses (e.g., examine interaction interpret main effects) depending outcome initial ANOVA model.Exercise 7 Evaluate model. checking necessary assumptions.Exercise 8 Generate publication worthy figures write-results.Let’s begin…

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
heading: 8.1 Exercise 1: Prepare RStudio and Import the Data
text: ’ll need packages:Import data set csv file called hazard.csv.View data familiarise :id: identifier.id: identifier.age: participant age years.age: participant age years.exp_code: code used log simulator experiment system participant.exp_code: code used log simulator experiment system participant.years_driving: many years driving.years_driving: many years driving.distraction: distraction condition randomly assigned .distraction: distraction condition randomly assigned .block1_car block2_car: number car hazards identified blocks 1 2 respectively.block1_car block2_car: number car hazards identified blocks 1 2 respectively.block1_bike block2_bike: number bike hazards identified blocks 1 2 respectively.block1_bike block2_bike: number bike hazards identified blocks 1 2 respectively.block1_pedestrian block2_pedestrian: number pedestrian hazards identified blocks 1 2 respectively.block1_pedestrian block2_pedestrian: number pedestrian hazards identified blocks 1 2 respectively.
code:
library(tidyverse)
library(afex)
library(car)
library(emmeans)
library(effectsize)

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
heading: 8.2 Exercise 2: Data Wrangling
text: data set bit busier seen , requires work ready analyse. normal part data analysis.need calculate total number hazards correctly identified, split two blocks moment.Question 3: R function help ? – choose answer –. filter()B. select()C. mutate()variables data set don’t really need, get rid clean data set want.Question 4: R function help ? – choose answer –. filter()B. select()C. mutate()data repeated measures variable wide format currently. need long format data.Question 5: R function help ? – choose answer –. pivot_longer()B. filter() C. group_by()Calculate Total ScoresThis code create three new variables: car, bike, pedestrian contain sum two blocks. used mutate() function week 1’s workshop.Can spot new variables created?Select Relevant VariablesUse names(mydata) list variables data set. Use code select variables need ANOVA analysis. need everything original mydata data set.example, really don’t need original block1_ block2_ scores now totals , similarly, exp_code needed analysis.Change NULL variable want keep (separated comma). used select() function week 1’s workshop. Note: code creates new object called mydata_clean don’t overwrite original mydata object.Use hint needed.notice fewer variables data set? looks bit tidier!Convert Wide Long formatThis create two new labels: hazard type hazard, acc number hazards correctly identified (accuracy). now use longd object.Re-code FactorsLast bit wrangling. Make sure factors coded Factor character.Now ready real analysis.
code:
mydata <- mydata %>%
  mutate(car = block1_car + block2_car,
         bike = block1_bike + block2_bike,
         pedestrian = block1_pedestrian + block2_pedestrian)
view(mydata)
mydata_clean <- mydata %>%
  select(NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL) # add as many as necessary
mydata_clean <- mydata %>%
  select(id, age, years_driving, distraction, car, bike, pedestrian)
view(mydata_clean)
longd <- mydata_clean %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = car:pedestrian,
    names_to = "hazard",
    values_to = "acc")
longd$distraction <- factor(longd$distraction)
longd$hazard <- factor(longd$hazard)

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
heading: 8.3 Exercise 3: Descriptive Stats and the Model
text:
Calculate descriptive statistics just like done previous weeks.Use names(longd) need reminder variable names.also generate box plot like (use code previous weeks) generate visualisations later .Now run initial ANOVA model…Take extra care ensure enter correct variable within lines code. Look back study scenario section start workshop need.Sphericity CheckAs one independent variables repeated measures need run extra check .aov_ez() automatically check Sphericity repeated measures variable three levels, essentially produce two ANOVA models: corrected model uncorrected model. need decide one use.assumption Sphericity violated, use corrected model.
assumption Sphericity met, can use uncorrected model.check, produce model output time using summary(mod) gives us extra information.Check output look Mauchly Tests Sphericity:report assumption based output , ’d write something like:
> Mauchly’s test indicated assumption sphericity violated main effect hazard, w = .96, p = .340 distraction × hazard interaction, W = .96 , p = .340.p-values -significant means Sphericity violated assumption met. now means can report ANOVA model without correction.assumption violated (either p-value less 0.05 therefore significant) use report corrected model. find just use:run now compare, ’ll notice degrees freedon slightly adjusted (’re whole numbers) values, p-values, might changed slightly. see Sphericity correction method: GG meand Greenhouse-Geisser correction applied include information write-.today’s scenario assumption met, continue wit uncorrected model.Interpret ANOVA model decide happen next…first main effect (distraction) – choose answer –significant SignificantThe second main effect (hazard type) – choose answer –significant SignificantThe distraction hazard type interaction – choose answer –significant Significant
code:
desc <- longd %>%
  group_by(NULL, NULL) %>%
    summarise(mean_acc = mean(NULL),
              sd_acc = sd(NULL))
view(desc)
mod <- aov_ez(id = "NULL",
              dv = "NULL",
              within = "NULL",
              between = "NULL",
              type = 3,
              include_aov = TRUE,
              data = NULL)
summary(mod)Mauchly Tests for Sphericity

                   Test statistic p-value
hazard                    0.96285 0.33993
distraction:hazard        0.96285 0.33993
nice(mod)

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
heading: 8.4 Exercise 4: Interpreting the Main effect of Distraction
text: two levels, can just use mean values interpret direction. can also use box plot .Question 9: statement correct interpretation main effect? – choose answer –. Hazard perception higher “distraction = Yes” condition B. Hazard perception higher “distraction = ” condition
code:
m_distract <- longd %>%
  group_by(NULL) %>%
    summarise(mean_acc = mean(NULL),
              sd_acc = sd(NULL))
view(m_distract)

ggplot(longd, aes(x = distraction, y = acc)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_classic()

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
heading: 8.5 Exercise 5: Interpreting the Main Effect of Hazard Type
text: two levels main effect, simply look means just yet, won’t clear conditions significantly different. main tell us least one significantly different, one?need follow steps one-way ANOVA (see Workshops 4 & 5 refresher). main effect significant, scenario run post-hoc multiple comparisons see differ. Work code figure best interpret main effect using:pairwise comparisonspairwise comparisonsbox plot visualising databox plot visualising datameans standard deviation descriptive statisticsmeans standard deviation descriptive statisticsYou used emmeans() function week 5’s workshop. Interpret output.Question 10: pairwise comparison significant? – choose answer –. bike vs. carB. car vs. pedestrianC. bike vs. pedestrianQuestion 11: Using available information, statement correct interpretation main effect? – choose answer –. Cars easier spot bikesB. Bikes easier spot pedestriansC. Cars easier spot pedestriansQuestion 12: Using available information, statement correct interpretation main effect? – choose answer –. Pedestrians significantly easier spot bikesB. Bikes pedestrians spotted equally oftenC. Bikes significantly easier spot pedestrians
code:
emmeans(mod,
        pairwise ~ hazard,
        adjust = "holm")
ggplot(longd, aes(x = hazard, y = acc)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_classic()
m_hazard <- longd %>%
  group_by(hazard) %>%
  summarise(mean_acc = mean(acc),
            sd_acc = sd(acc))
view(m_hazard)

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
heading: 8.6 Exercise 6: Effect Sizes
text: far initial ANOVA model gave :F, df, p main effect interaction.Descriptive statistics main effect distraction gave :Mean standard deviation identified hazard two groups (yes, presence distraction)Descriptive statistics pairwise comparisons main effect hazard type gave :Mean standard deviation identified hazards three conditions (car, bike, pedestrian hazard type) t, df, p pairwise comparisons three.effect sizes?ANOVA model, look partial eta squared (\(η_P^2\)). super quick easy check ANOVA model mod using code:can report full F-statement APA format like :F(df1, df2) = value, p = value, \(η_P^2\) = valueAnything underlined needs replaced values output far.pairwise comparisons, bit tricky depends variable main effect independent () repeated (within) measures. independent measures follow code last week’s workshop (see cohens_d).repeated design can use code t-test workshop earlier term. **One annoying need go back use original mydata data rare occasion wide data preferred (annoying, right?!)need match three comparisons carried exercise 4.Question 13: pairwise comparison largest effect size? – choose answer –. Car vs. PedestrianB. Bike vs. PedestrianC. Car vs. Bike
code:
eta_squared(mod)
cohens_d(mydata$car, mydata$bike, paired = TRUE)
cohens_d(mydata$car, mydata$pedestrian, paired = TRUE)
cohens_d(mydata$pedestrian, mydata$bike, paired = TRUE)

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
heading: 8.7 Exercise 7: Evaluating Assumptions
text: Sphericity already checker earlier . mixed design, now two assumptions check.

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
heading: 8.7.1 Checking Normality
text: done . code, providing ANOVA model called mod.
code:
# testing normality, looking at normal distribution of residuals from the model.
residuals <- residuals(mod) #pulls residuals from the model
qqPlot(residuals) #produces a qq-plot of residuals
hist(residuals, breaks = 20, main = "Histogram of Residuals", xlab = "Residuals", col = "lightblue") #histogram of residuals
shapiro.test(residuals) #Shapiro test for residuals

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
heading: 8.7.2 Checking Homogeneity of Variance
text: use Levene’s test. ’ve also done one-way independent ANOVA.Change NULL1 dependent variable.Change NULL2 independent (subjects) measures independent variable.third item object contains data, case longd .Remember, non-significant p-value (>.05) means assumption met.
code: leveneTest(NULL1 ~ NULL2, longd)

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA

text: considering data visualisation options, consider “significant important findings want show reader?”. Given two significant main effects non-significant interaction, present figure showing interaction, ’re teling full story.Use code generate three plots. Take look interpret show.

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
heading: 8.8.1 Plot 1
code:
p1 <- ggplot(longd, aes(x = distraction, y = acc)) +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "bar", 
               position = position_dodge(), 
               color = "black",
               fill = c("slategray4", "slategray2")) +
  stat_summary(fun.data = mean_se, geom = "errorbar", 
               position = position_dodge(0.9), width = 0.25) +
  labs(
    title = NULL,
    x = "Distraction",
    y = "Mean Number of Hazards Identified") +
  scale_x_discrete(labels = c("yes" = "Yes", "no" = "No")) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.border = element_rect(color = "black", fill = NA, size = 1),
    plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
    axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
    axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))

  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "bar", 
               position = position_dodge(), 
               color = "black",
               fill = c("slategray4", "slategray2", "darkslategray3")) +
  stat_summary(fun.data = mean_se, geom = "errorbar", 
               position = position_dodge(0.9), width = 0.25) +
  labs(
    title = NULL,
    x = "Hazard Type",
    y = "Mean Hazards Identified") +

  theme(
    panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),

chapter: 8 Workshop 8: Factorial ANOVA: Mixed Design Factorial ANOVA
heading: 8.8.3 Plot 3
text:
run three, use code present three .
’ll need new package.NOTE: likely need resize output panel (bottom right panel) making wider three plots visible.Question 14: plot tells us main effect distraction? – choose answer –. Plot 1 (p1)B. Plot 2 (p2)C. Plot 3 (p3)Question 15: plot tells us main effect hazard? – choose answer –. Plot 1 (p1)B. Plot 2 (p2)C. Plot 3 (p3)Question 16: plot tells us interaction? – choose answer –. Plot 1 (p1)B. Plot 2 (p2)C. Plot 3 (p3)
code:
p3 <- ggplot(longd, aes(x = hazard, y = acc, fill = distraction)) +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "bar", position = position_dodge(), color = "black") +
  stat_summary(fun.data = mean_se, geom = "errorbar", 
               position = position_dodge(0.9), width = 0.25) +
  labs(
    title = NULL,   # leave this as NULL because APA figures do not use titles.
    x = "Hazard",
    y = "Mean Number of Hazards Identified",
    fill = "Distraction") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("yes" = "slategray4", "no" = "slategray2"), 
                    labels = c("Yes", "No")) +
  scale_x_discrete(labels = c("car" = "Car", "bike" = "Bike", "pedestrian" = "Pedestrian")) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.border = element_rect(color = "black", fill = NA, size = 1),
    plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
    legend.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
    axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
install.packages("gridExtra")
library(gridExtra)

grid.arrange(p1,p2,p3, ncol = 3)

heading: 9 Workshop 9: Non-Parametric Statistics
text: Aims:Practice importing wrangling data ready analysis.Practice using non-parametric statistics one-way repeated design, including follow-analyses.

heading: 9.1 Exercise 1: Import and Prepare Data
text: Import data set called exercise.csvThis data set looked average number hours per week university students engaged form physical exercise, across three time points: , , university. repeated measures design.aim study determine levels physical exercise changed time.data long format. Use code change changing NULL necessary. code assumes saved original data set object called mydata.probably code time factor, also reorder levels. standard, multiple levels, RStudio pop alphabetical order. However, levels meaningful order. moment alphabetically : , , druing unhelpful.Change ’re correct order: , , . Change NULL code .##Exercise 2: Descriptive StatisticsChange NULL code . Remember, using non-parametric statistics consider want use mean something else…##Exercise 3: Friedman’s ANOVARun ANOVA ask effect size. Remember use formula DV ~ IV | id. Change NULLInterpret output. main effect significant, post-hoc tests needed. Amend code changing NULL data set variables correct place.
code:
library(tudyverse)
library(rstatix)
view(mydata)
names(mydata)
longd <- mydata %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(NULL:NULL),
               names_to = "time",
               values_to = "exercise")
               
view(longd) #take a look at what the above code has done. nice and long!longd$time <- factor(longd$time, levels = c("NULL", "NULL", "NULL"))
desc <- longd %>%
  group_by(NULL) %>%
  summarise(median = NULL(NULL))

view(desc)
ggplot(mydata_long, aes(x = time, y = exercise)) +
  geom_violin() +
  geom_boxplot(width = 0.2) +
  theme_classic()
friedman.test(NULL ~ NULL | NULL, data = longd)
friedman_effsize(NULL ~ NULL | NULL, data = longd)
longd %>%
  pairwise_wilcox_test(
    NULL ~ BULL,
    paired = TRUE,
    p.adjust.method = "holm")
    
wilcox_effsize(NULLL ~ NULL, data = longd, paired = TRUE)

heading: 9.2 Code for all Four Non-Parametric Tests
text: code four statistics covered lecture. included might want code year 3 final year project, use non-parametric analyses project data analysis.

heading: 9.3 Code for Mann-Whitney U (or Wilcoxon Rank-Sum)
text: use code need change:DV dependent variable.IV independent variable.DATA name object data.
code:
wilcox.test(DV ~ IV, data = DATA) # provides W and p statistics
wilcox_effsize(rt ~ drink, data = mydata) # provides rank-biserial correlation r statistic and magnitude

heading: 9.4 Code for Kruskal-Wallis
text: DV dependent variable.IV independent variable.DATA name object data.
code:
kruskal.test(DV ~ IV, data = DATA)
kruskal_effsize(DV ~ IV, data = DATA)

#pairwirse comparisons if main effect is signifcant
DATA %>%
  pairwise_wilcox_test(
    DV ~ IV,
    paired = FALSE,
    p.adjust.method = "holm")
    
wilcox_effsize(DV ~ IV, data = DATA) # provides rank-biserial correlation r statistic and magnitude

heading: 9.5 Code for Wilcoxon-Signed Rank
text: DV dependent variable.IV independent variable.DATA name object data.data need long format analysis, repeated measures design.
code:
pairwise_wilcox_test(DV ~ IV, data = DATA, paired = TRUE)
wilcox_effsize(DV ~ IV, data = DATA, paired = TRUE) # provides rank-biserial correlation r statistic and magnitude

heading: 9.6 Code for Friedman’s ANOVA
text: DV dependent variable.IV independent variable.DATA name object data.id name id variable (identifier participant)data need long format analysis, repeated measures design.
code:
friedman.test(DV ~ IV | id, data = DATA)
friedman_effsize(DV ~ IV | id, data = DATA)

#pairwirse comparisons if main effect is signifcant
DATA %>%
  pairwise_wilcox_test(
    DV ~ IV,
    paired = TRUE,
    p.adjust.method = "holm")
wilcox_effsize(DV ~ IV, data = DATA, paired = TRUE)
